SiteDescription:
The Royal London Hospital is home to one of the largest children’s hospitals in the UK with one of London's busiest paediatric accident and emergency departments.

It is also home to London’s Air Ambulance service and one of the capital's leading trauma and emergency care centres and hyper-acute stroke centres.

The Breathe London Node is located near the entrance to A&E to assess the exposure of visitors, patients and staff at the hospital.
OtherTags: Deployed, GLA, Solar300, Tower Hamlets, V1

SiteDescription:
North Middlesex University Hospital has been serving the community for over a century. The first hospital buildings on the present site were built in 1909.

The hospital has expanded and modernised over the years, improving the medical, surgical, stroke and children’s services including a brand new maternity and neonatal unit. The new maternity unit is equipped with with state-of-the-art facilities and is among the best NHS maternity units in the country.

The Breathe London Node is located by the front entrance and serves to assess the exposure of visitors, patients and staff at the hospital.
OtherTags: Deployed, GLA, Haringey, Mains1, V1

SiteDescription:
Newham University Hospital serves one of the most diverse populations in England. The hospital cares for more than 500 patients in its A&E department every day and is home to one of the largest maternity units in the UK with more than 6,000 births each year.

The hospital's state-of-the-art Rainbow Centre is geared up to meet the needs of its young patients and their families in a child-friendly environment. 

The Breathe London Node is located on a flag pole by the entrance to the A&E department where patients are picked up and dropped off.
OtherTags: Deployed, GLA, Newham, Solar300, V1

SiteDescription:
Whipps Cross Hospital has a strong reputation as a centre of excellence for various specialist services, including urology, ENT, audiology, cardiology, colorectal surgery, cancer care and acute stroke care.

Thanks to £6.7m in funding from Barts Charity, the hospital is making a series of improvements to its Maternity and Neonatal services to improve the environment and prepare for an increase in birth rates in its local population. This will include a dedicated clinical research hub for women's services.

The Breathe London Node is located by the main entrance near the car park to assess exposure for staff, patients and visitors.
OtherTags: Deployed, GLA, Solar300, V1, Waltham Forest

SiteDescription:
Charing Cross Hospital provides a range of acute and specialist services, a 24/7 accident and emergency department and hosts the hyper acute stroke unit for the region.

It is also a growing hub for integrated care in partnership with local GPs and community providers.

The Breathe London Node is located on a wall near the entrance on Fulham Palace Road.
OtherTags: Deployed, GLA, Hammersmith and Fulham, Mains1, V1

SiteDescription:
The Royal Marsden Hospital opened in 1851 as the world’s first hospital dedicated to cancer diagnosis, treatment, research and education.

Today it operates as a specialist cancer hospital and National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Biomedical Research Centre for Cancer, working closely with its principal academic partner, the Institute of Cancer Research (ICR).

The Breathe London Node is located on railings near the main entrance on the Fulham Road.
OtherTags: Deployed, GLA, Kensington and Chelsea, Mains1, V1

SiteDescription:
Established in 1828 by William Marsden, the Royal Free's founding principle was that they would take in anyone who needed treatment – the first hospital in London to do so and the only London hospital to stay open during the 19th-century cholera epidemics.

In the 21st century, the hospital continues to lead improvements in healthcare and is proud to have some of the best clinical outcomes in the country.

The Breathe London Node is located in the busy pick-up and drop-off area by the entrance assessing exposure of staff, visitors and patients.
OtherTags: Camden, Deployed, GLA, Solar300, V1

SiteDescription:

Since its formation in 1852, the hospital has been dedicated to children’s healthcare and to finding new and better ways to treat childhood illnesses.

The Breathe London Node is located by the main entrance which receives 237,908 outpatient visits and 43,218 inpatient visits every year.

SiteName: Horn Link Way j/w Peartree Way
SiteDescription:
This node is solar powered and mounted on a lamppost in a roadside location.  The node is positioned here to review levels of pollution arising from both road traffic and fugitive emissions from industry.
The location is adjacent to part of the Greenwich Millennium Village, a strategic regeneration site within the Royal Borough of Greenwich. It received planning permission circa 2012 to deliver new residential units along with commercial, retail and community uses. The scheme has been built out in phases and has delivered a significant number of residential units that have made an important contribution to the annual housing targets within the Borough. The residential developments are bordered by long standing industry including, aggregate and cement works, and waste transfer operations. These industries supply an array of materials to support the construction sector and infrastructure projects in both Greenwich and the wider city.
OtherTags: Deployed, Greenwich, Quid Pro Quo, Solar300, V1

SiteName: Ceres Road, j/w Bannockburn Road - Bannockburn Primary School
SiteDescription:
This node is solar powered and mounted on a lamppost to capture levels of pollution from road traffic in the vicinity. 
Bannockburn Primary School is a diverse learning community located in Plumstead that provides the best possible support in enabling pupils to achieve their best. The school is spread across two sites both located within the Plumstead area. Pupils from Reception to Year 2 are based at the High Street site which is closest to where the node is located. The school has high aspirations for pupils, their families and the community of Plumstead. The Schools Vision is 'Growing Together, Learning for Life'.
The area surrounding the school site has been identified as having a high proportion of private rented housing, and in particular Houses in multiple occupation (HMO). With a localised Nepalese speaking community, the Council's Environmental and Housing Services are working closely with charity and community groups to better engage with this community on Environmental and Housing matters.

SiteName: Greenwich University -Student Unon , Avery Hill Campus
SiteDescription:
This node is solar powered and mounted on a lamppost outside the student union building of the Avery Hill Campus of Greenwich University. Avery Hill Campus is located in Eltham, South-East London. It has first-rate teaching and sporting facilities, as well as student accommodation. There are four clinical skills laboratories, and two floodlit, all-weather sport pitches on Campus. The Campus specialises in nursing, medicine, and social work, with a huge health and social care teaching space on campus, as well as sports with a multi-purpose sports hall and a 220-seat lecture theatre. The University has strong partnerships with Charlton Athletic FC, whose training ground is based next to the campus.
The educational health focus of this site includes an interest in air quality from users of the campus.

The square is home to a council-run market, dating back to the 1600s, selling general goods, providing bike repairs and food vendors with outdoor seating. The market operates six days per week and includes the location of the main gate of the old Royal Arsenal. The surrounding area includes the Woolwich Arsenal DLR Station, Beresford Street (A206), and the Woolwich redevelopment site at Royal Arsenal; a waterside housing and retail development area adjacent to the new Crossrail station.

SiteDescription:
The site is a kerbside location adjacent to a moderately busy road right in the centre of the borough of Hackney.
At this point, Amhurst Road is predominantly residential. The properties consist of a mix of residential blocks as well as some larger, older houses, many of which have been converted into separate residential units. Therefore, there will be a relatively high number of people in the area who may be affected by air pollution.
Among these are the residents of the Downs Estate. The estate includes 210 homes and is managed by a Tenant Management Organisation. The TMO has been instrumental in delivering improvements to the homes and this has included planting and landscaping works. Locating a Breathe London Node on their doorstep provides an opportunity to help further the interests of residents in their local environment and to see changes in air pollution over time. This we hope can encourage behaviour change and also help to raise awareness of their successes.

SiteDescription:
Air pollution is a serious issue, which  affects all of us, whether foetus, child, adult and elderly.
In the autumn 2021 a group of locals got together and created a community group 'Clean Air Bayswater’  to find a way to reduce the air pollution levels in our area.
We applied for and were very pleased  to be granted a Breathe London air pollution monitor, which will enable us to track and address air pollution in our local area.
We have developed a 12 month local community campaign to raise awareness among residents, businesses, schools and GPs of air pollution and how it impacts our health, irrespective of our age. This will involve a school education programme,  community events for residents and local business engagement activities.
Our aim is to improve the air we breathe by asking everyone living or working in Bayswater to join in, and take some simple steps to reduce air pollution in our area.  We are looking to work with other clean air groups to collaborate and share learning, so that we can all make as big a difference as possible.
We will also be looking for Westminster City Council to take action to support our campaign and actively reduce key issues such as idling.  
We believe that together we can make a difference.   Air pollution affects our lungs, heart and brains. We need to take action now. There is no excuse - The Clean Air Bayswater Group
OtherTags: Clean Air Bayswater, Deployed, Mains1, V2, Westminster

SiteDescription:
Healthy Streets North Tottenham are a group of local residents striving for better, less polluted streets. We came together in 2020 to tackle the dominance that through-traffic has on our neighbourhood.

The rise in traffic has had a disproportionate effect on North Tottenham and the people who live here. Every day, residents experience 5000 vehicles passing their homes, which severely impacts our health, safety, lifestyle, social connections and ability to build a strong community. 

By harnessing the air quality data captured by this node, we hope to be able to persuade decision-makers at Haringey Council to take action on the ill effects of traffic pollution and implement changes which work for and benefit local residents. It will also help to raise awareness within the community and encourage others to tackle air pollution in North Tottenham.

SiteDescription:
Victoria Park Harriers and Tower Hamlets Athletics Club is based at St. Augustine’s Hall in the north-east corner of Victoria Park in Tower Hamlets, London. It was formed in 2001 as a merger of Victoria Park Harriers (founded in 1926) and Tower Hamlets Athletics Club (founded in 1976). The club is open to all regardless of ability from the age of 9 upwards and coached training sessions occur at St. Augustine’s Hall, Mile End Stadium and the London Marathon Community Track at least twice a week. The active membership of approximately 450 athletes includes track, field, road and cross-country athletes, from beginners to Olympians. The club reflects the diversity of East London and has close links to local schools through our junior athletes.

While Mile End Stadium and the London Marathon Community Track are both over 50 metres away from busy roads and thus classified as urban background locations, St. Augustine’s Hall is about 20 metres from the A106, close to the junction with the A12, which results in poor air quality, as reported by the Breathe GB campaign, which found that St. Augustine’s Hall had the worst air quality of any sports facility in England with an average of 67 µg/m3 of NO2 and 17 µg/m3 of PM2.5 in 2018.

The Club is looking forward to using the data from the Breathe London node, which will improve the ability of Club members and local residents to avoid high pollution episodes and provide them with the data necessary to advocate for measures to improve local air quality.

SiteDescription: This monitor was secured by Woodford Green resident Lydia Fraser-Ward to measure the levels of air pollutants in Elmhurst Gardens, E18. After spending two years visiting the park every day with her toddler, she became increasingly concerned about the air quality in the children’s playground and the effect it could be having on her son’s health. This area of the park backs onto the North Circular / A406 where it meets a major interchange with the M11 at the Charlie Brown’s Roundabout. After weeks of research she found that there were no air monitors provided by the local authority in the nearby vicinity, and that there was very limited data recorded specifically in parks and play areas relating to air pollution. Lydia joined clean air campaign group Mums for Lungs and reached out to a number of community groups, schools, environmental projects and parents in the local area to raise awareness about this issue. With their support she put together a short film to apply to the Breathe London Community Programme for this air quality node. The data will be used to inform whether further mitigation measures are needed to protect park and playground users from the motorway’s toxic air.

We want to use data from our Breathe London Node as a starter for improvements in air quality for those using and working in the Brunswick shopping centre, as well as those of us who live here.

SiteDescription:
Ray Lodge Primary School is set in the heart of Woodford Green next to Ray Park. Although it enjoys the wildlife, biodiversity and picturesque setting that this green space provides, it is also situated on a busy road which runs under the M11 situated close by. Mums for Lungs Redbridge - a grassroots organisation made up of local residents all connected by a shared concern about air quality - was keen to work with the school to monitor levels of localised pollution coming from traffic on nearby roads and how this may be affecting the outdoor play areas of the school. 
 
Our group actively campaigns throughout the London Borough of Redbridge for more air quality monitoring in outdoor play areas and gyms, whilst also supporting parents to set up School Streets and raises awareness of the risks of idling car engines and wood burning. This monitor was secured by Woodford Green resident Rachel Southern in partnership with Mums for Lungs Redbridge Coordinator Lydia Fraser-Ward. Lydia was fortunate enough to receive an air monitor in Round 1 of the Breathe London Community Programme for the children’s outdoor playground in Elmhurst Gardens, South Woodford, which is located next to the North Circular.
 
The data from this Breathe London node will be used to inform the school and local residents of levels of nitrogen dioxide and particulate matter in the area. This information will be highly valuable and will inform whether further mitigation measures are needed to reduce air pollution levels around the school, whilst raising awareness more generally with parents about air quality in the neighbourhood.

SiteDescription:
About the group

REACH (Residents Environmental Action on Climate and Health) is a sub group of the Hampstead Garden Suburb (HGS) Residents association with a number of key stated aims including ;
•        To support Suburb residents in preparation for environmental challenges by taking initiatives that will play a part in reducing our contribution to emissions and thus to the warming of the planet 
•        Consider actions we can take to reduce local pollution and enhance biodiversity.
•        Consult and co-operate with LB Barnet, HGS Trust, City of London, Transport for London, Environment Agency, and other relevant bodies as applicable.
•        Aim is to achieve Net Zero greenhouse gas emissions from the area by 2040 and to work with residents and relevant stakeholders to achieve this ambitious target.
Node location 

One key area of concern that REACH has identified within HGS is air quality (AQ) as the Suburb is bordered and dissected by some of London’s busiest roads, including the A40, the A1, East End Road and the Finchley Road. The lack of meaningful AQ data within the suburb means we can’t take steps to identify and address the root cause (whether it is vehicles, buildings, or wood burners), educate residents and inform change in HGS and the wider area. There is, perhaps, a preconception that there is no AQ problem in the suburb because it is indeed founded on the Garden City principles of open green spaces. However. Whilst there is an obvious impact on residents and businesses that border these roads it also creates and number of “rat runs”  Meadway is one of these roads, it is also part of the H2 bus route .

SiteDescription:
Like other areas of London, we know that the South Bank and people who live, work and visit here are adversely affected by ambient air pollution, with concentrations of nitrogen dioxide a particular concern. However, real-time air pollution monitoring in the South Bank has previously been limited to St Thomas’ Hospital. We have therefore commissioned a high-density mini network of eight measurement nodes to give a picture of current pollution levels across a range of locations that reflect the different urban environments found across the South Bank. This will give us great baseline data to help inform future environmental improvement projects.

Belvedere Road is a quiet road but it is regularly used by coaches and tour buses, which have bus stands along it. It is used by a mixture of residents, employees and tourists, with people frequently spending periods of time within Jubilee Gardens which are adjacent to the Belvedere Road node. Thank you to Lambeth Council for hosting the node on their land.

The South Bank Business Improvement District (BID) was set up in 2014 to improve the management of South Bank in the face of increasing footfall and falling public spending. We fund and support several public realm services, including enhanced security, cleaning and litter picking, and help to promote South Bank as a leading visitor destination and as the cultural heart of London. We are a voice for South Bank businesses and provide a wealth of networking opportunities to the organisations in our BID area through event and networking programmes.

The work of South Bank BID is achieved by working in collaboration with others who share our vision for the future prosperity of the South Bank, including South Bank Employers’ Group, South Bank and Waterloo Partnership, the Visitor Management Group, South Bank Marketing and Venues Groups and South Bank Business Watch. South Bank BID is an independent organisation, governed by a Board of Directors drawn from a range of businesses within the BID area and who work to support all our levy paying members and to represent their views.

SiteDescription:
Air on the Green would like to better understand the significance of charcoal burning and other unfiltered particulate emissions from restaurants on air quality and health. The concern is that high levels of particulates in unfiltered restaurant pollution might be putting residents at risk of a range of health impacts, including respiratory and cardiovascular risks. 
 
Legislation passed in 2021 now makes it illegal to emit visible smoke from a chimney. However currently the local council does not act on complaints.
The installation of an air monitoring node in an enclave of student housing, flats and houses protected from road pollution but vulnerable to pollution from charcoal burning in restaurants to both north and south (depending on the direction of the wind) is an interesting opportunity to assess the impact of restaurants on local air quality. 
The node will enable us to gather and disseminate crucial data, which we hope will raise awareness of any effect on public health of charcoal burning, and of the potential to improve air quality by means of filtration. 
If the impact of charcoal burning in restaurants is found to be a significant concern, we hope to use this data to set a precedent for communities across the country affected by the same issue so that we can more effectively campaign to our councils. It is also our hope that a case can be made for a scrappage scheme for extraction ducts that could result in a significant improvement in urban air quality. Such a scrappage scheme would help defuse the tensions that inevitably arise when one group asks another group to spend money on improvements.

SiteDescription:
The Friends of Limehouse are taking a systematic approach towards improving our natural environment, which includes reducing air pollution. 

Air pollution levels in Limehouse are amongst the highest in London and are the highest in LB Tower Hamlets by 30%.  The levels are recorded by an LBTH sensor (No35) located to the west of the Limehouse Link and Rotherhithe tunnel portals, and to the junction of Branch Road with Commercial Road, where excessive traffic congestion is common. 

The new Breathe London sensor is located in Branch Road on the east side of the pollution source where levels are likely to be higher than at the existing sensor due the prevailing westerly wind.

We have provided proposals to the authorities on how traffic congestion and hence pollution might be reduced at its source; and have obtained proposals by specialist consultants for a Green Infrastructure Masterplan, including air pollution reduction at its source and beyond.  The GI Masterplan would provide many other benefits such as active travel, community cohesion and enhanced biodiversity.

The additional sensor now located on Branch Road will be invaluable in providing further evidence for the approval of the measures necessary to reduce air pollution and to monitor subsequent improvements.

SiteName: Mary Immaculate and St. Peter's Church
SiteDescription: Several factors have come together to highlight the importance of understanding the quality of the air we breath in and around Chipping Barnet Foodbank. Firstly, we are a service that supports vulnerable people in our community. Many of our clients have adverse medical conditions and experience poverty. When these factors are combined with poor air quality, we know that this can make for significantly worse health outcomes. Secondly, we are based near one of the larger construction sites in the London Borough of Barnet called The Victoria Quarter. In fact, we used to be based on this site and we now reside a couple of hundred metres up the road. It is estimated that 19% of air pollution in Barnet is caused by construction sites. A third factor is the introduction of the Ultra Low Emission Zone (ULEZ). Barnet has been deeply emersed in the debate about ULEZ and passions run high in the suburb. Considering these factors, we are delighted to have a node which is based just outside the entrance to our hall, and which will accurately capture the life of the foodbank from client footfall to delivery traffic to our small carpark. We plan to use the node as an educational platform for the food bank, the parish, and the local community with a view to monitoring and campaigning for good air quality inside as well as outside
